p.draft-comment: The following IgnoreControlChar-row is used in Configuring a - Directory, File Tail, Kafka Consumer, Kinesis Consumer, JSON Parser, Log Parser:]

row.entry: Removes all ASCII control characters except for the tab, line feed, and carriage return characters.

p.draft-comment: Origin - first step rows for event handling origins

row.entry: Generates event records when events occur. Use for event handling.

Error record handling for the stage:
Discard - Discards the record.
Send to Error - Sends the record to the pipeline for error handling.
Stop Pipeline - Stops the pipeline.

p.draft-comment: ORIGIN rows - ProduceSingleRec is used by Kafka Consumer and MapR Streams Consumer. MaxBatchSize and BatchWaitTime rows are used in Configuring Kafka Consumer, JMS Consumer, Salesforce origin, Salesforce Lookup. See if they should go anywhere else.
Charsets are used by message and file origins. But Directory Charset is standalone.

row.entry:
For each partition, generates a single record for records that include multiple objects.
When not selected, the origin generates multiple records when a record includes multiple objects.

Maximum number of records processed at one time. Honors values up to the maximum batch size.
Default is 1000. The default is 1000.
Number of milliseconds to wait before sending a partial or empty batch.
Character encoding of the messages to be processed.
Character encoding of the files to be processed.
Character encoding of the data to be processed.

p.draft-comment: The following rows are used in the Data Collector Console - Overview,

strow.stentry: Provides context-sensitive help based on the information in the panel.

p.draft-comment: The following row is used in Configuring Hive Streaming

entry.p: Use to override the default field to column mappings.
By default, fields are written to columns of the same name.

p.draft-comment: The following descriptions are used by the AWS destinations: Amazon S3, Kinesis Firehose, Kinesis Producer. And by writing aggregated statistics to Kinesis, in DPM chapter > Aggregated Statistics for Pipelines > Configuring a Pipeline to Aggregate Statistics

entry.p: AWS access key ID.
Required when not using IAM roles with IAM instance profile credentials.
AWS secret access key.
Required when not using IAM roles with IAM instance profile credentials.

p.draft-comment: The following descriptions are used by the AWS origins: Amazon S3 and Kinesis Consumer.

entry.p: AWS access key ID.
Required when not using IAM roles with IAM instance profile credentials.
AWS secret access key.
Required when not using IAM roles with IAM instance profile credentials.

p.draft-comment: The following rows are used in full for the Amazon S3 origin. The Amazon S3 destination and Kinesis Firehose destination reuse individual rows. Data Format, File Compression, and File Name Pattern within Compressed Directory are also used in Directory, File Tail, HTTP Client, and SFTP Client.

row.entry: Endpoint to connect to when you select Other for the region. Enter the endpoint name.
Bucket that contains the objects to be read.
Optional common prefix that describes the location of the objects. When defined, the common prefix acts as a root for the prefix pattern.

Delimiter used by Amazon S3 to define the prefix hierarchy.
Default is slash ( / ).
Includes system-defined and user-defined metadata in record header attributes.

Prefix pattern that describes the objects to be processed.
You can include the entire path to the objects. You can also use Ant-style path patterns to read objects recursively.

Maximum buffer size. The buffer size determines the size of the record that can be processed.
Decrease when memory on the machine is limited. Increase to process larger records when memory is available.
Default is 128 KB.

The compression format of the files:
None - Processes only uncompressed files.
Compressed File - Processes files compressed by the supported compression formats.
Archive - Processes files archived by the supported archive formats.
Compressed Archive - Processes files archived and compressed by the supported archive and compression formats.
File Name Pattern within Compressed Directory

File name pattern that represents the files to process within the compressed directory. You can use UNIX-style wildcards, such as an asterisk or question mark. For example, *.json.
Default is *, which processes all files.

Data format for source files. Use one of the following formats:
Avro
Delimited
JSON
Log
Protobuf
SDC Record
Text
Whole File
XML

conbody.draft-comment: Kinesis Consumer, Kinesis Producer and DPM chapter > Aggregated Statistics for Pipelines > Configuring a Pipeline to Aggregate Statistics use these rows

row.entry: Amazon Web Services region that hosts the Kinesis cluster.
Endpoint to connect to when you select Other for the region. Enter the endpoint name.

Strategy to write data to Kinesis shards:
Random - Generates a random partition key.
Expression - Uses the result of an expression as the partition key.

Expression to generate the partition key used to pass data to different shards.
Use for the expression partition strategy.

Additional Kinesis properties.
When you add a configuration property, enter the exact property name and the value. The Kinesis Producer does not validate the property names or values.

p.draft-comment: HTTP Client origin, processor, and destination rows:

row.entry:
Use one of the following encoding types:
Buffered - The standard transfer encoding type.
Chunked - Transfers data in chunks. Not supported by all servers.
The default is Chunked.

Maximum number of milliseconds to wait for a connection.
Use 0 to wait indefinitely.

Maximum number of milliseconds to wait for data.
Use 0 to wait indefinitely.

Determines the authentication type used to connect to the server:
None - Performs no authentication.
Basic - Uses basic authentication. Requires a username and password.
Use with HTTPS to avoid passing unencrypted credentials.
Digest - Uses digest authentication. Requires a username and password.
Universal - Makes an anonymous connection, then provides authentication credentials upon receiving a 401 status and a WWW-Authenticate header request.
Requires a username and password associated with basic or digest authentication.
Use only with servers that respond to this workflow.
OAuth - Uses OAuth 1.0 authentication. Requires OAuth credentials.

Enables using OAuth 2 authorization to request access tokens.
You can use OAuth 2 authorization with none, basic, digest, or universal authentication.

entry.p: Enables using an HTTP proxy to connect to the system.

row.entry: Maximum number of seconds to wait for a request to complete.

Maximum number of requests to make per second. Set a rate limit when sending requests to a rate-limited API.
Default is 0, which means there is no delay between requests.

conbody.draft-comment: OAuth 2 table for HTTP Client origin, processor, and destination

row.entry:
Type of client credentials grant type required by the HTTP service:
Client credentials grant
Resource owner password credentials grant
JSON Web Tokens (JWT)
URL to request the access token.

Client ID that the HTTP service uses to identify the HTTP client.
Enter for the client credentials grant that uses a client ID and secret for authentication. Or, for the resource owner password credentials grant that requires a client ID and secret.

Client secret that the HTTP service uses to authenticate the HTTP client.
Enter for the client credentials grant that uses a client ID and secret for authentication. Or, for the resource owner password credentials grant that requires a client ID and secret.

Resource owner user name.
Enter for the resource owner password credentials grant.

Resource owner password.
Enter for the resource owner password credentials grant.

Algorithm used to sign the JSON Web Token (JWT).
Default is none. Enter for the JSON Web Tokens grant.

Base64 encoded key used to sign the JSON Web Token, if you selected a signing algorithm.
Enter for the JSON Web Tokens grant.

Form of encoding to use when the stage requests an access token: buffered or chunked.
Default is buffered.

Optional key-value pairs to send to the token URL when requesting an access token. For example, you can define the OAuth 2 scope request parameter.
Use the Add icon to add additional key-value pairs.

Algorithm to use to hash field values:
MD5 - Produces a 128-bit (16-byte) hash value, typically expressed in text format as a 32 digit hexadecimal number.
SHA1 - Produces a 160-bit (20-byte) hash value.
SHA2 - Based on SHA1, but uses a set of four hash functions: 224, 256, 384, or 512 bits.
MURMUR3_128 - Produces a 128-bit (16 byte) hash value.
Field in the record to use for hashed data. If the field does not exist, Field Hasher creates the field.
Attribute in the record header to use for hashed data. If the attribute does not exist, Field Hasher creates the attribute.

conbody.draft-comment: The Hive Metadata processor and the Hive Metastore destination configuring topics use these individual rows and the Max entries description. Hive Query executor also uses rows.

row.entry: JDBC URL for Hive. You can use the default, or replace the expression for the database name with a specific database name when appropriate.

entry.p: Absolute path to the directory containing the Hive and Hadoop configuration files. For a Cloudera Manager installation, enter hive-conf.
The stage uses the following configuration files:
entry.note: Properties in the configuration files are overridden by individual properties defined in this stage.

entry.p: Additional properties to use.
To add properties, click Add and define the property name and value. Use the property names and values as expected by HDFS and Hive.

row.entry:
Maximum number of entries in the cache.
When the cache reaches the maximum size, the oldest cached entries are evicted to allow for new data.
Default is -1, an unlimited cache size.

conbody.draft-comment: Event destinations and executors, 1st step. Rows used.

row.entry: Library version that you want to use.
Generates event records when events occur. Use for event handling.

Fields that must include data for the record to be passed into the stage. You might include fields that the stage uses.
Records that do not include all required fields are processed based on the error handling configured for the pipeline.

Conditions that must evaluate to TRUE to allow a record to enter the stage for processing. Click Add to create additional preconditions.
Records that do not meet all preconditions are processed based on the error handling configured for the stage.

Error record handling for the stage:
Discard - Discards the record.
Send to Error - Sends the record to the pipeline for error handling.
Stop Pipeline - Stops the pipeline.

p.draft-comment: Hadoop FS, MapR FS, Local FS use D-Event-RHattributes in Event Records. All others use the creation_date entry: entry-Event-creationDate.

row.entry:
Event type. Uses one of the following types:
file-closed - Generated when the destination closes a file.
wholeFileProcessed - Generated when the destination completes streaming a whole file.
An integer that indicates the version of the event record type.
Epoch timestamp when the stage created the event.

p.draft-comment: Table used by Salesforce Event Record and Multitable JDBC. JDBC Query uses the no-more-data bullet.

row.entry:
Event type. Uses the following type:
no-more-data - Generated when the origin completes processing all data returned by a query.
Character set to use when writing files.
Character set to use when writing data.

p.draft-comment: table-JDBCProps - JDBC Query Consumer, Multi Table JDBC Consumer, JDBC Lookup, JDBC Producer, and JDBC Tee use most rows in this table. Oracle CDC is using a couple too. JDBC Query executor also uses some. – no one uses the whole table AFAI can tell.<lc>

row.entry:
Connection string to use to connect to the database.
Some databases, such as Postgres, require the schema in the connection string. Use the connection string format required by the database.

Use to override the default field to column mappings. By default, fields are written to columns of the same name.
When you override the mappings, you can define parameterized values to apply SQL functions to the field values before writing them to columns. For example, to convert a field value to an integer, enter the following for the parameterized value:CAST(? AS INTEGER)
The question mark (?) is substituted with the value of the field. Leave the default value of ? if you do not need to apply a SQL function.
Use the Add icon to create additional field to column mappings.

Amount of time to wait between queries. Enter an expression based on a unit of time. You can use SECONDS, MINUTES, or HOURS.
Default is 10 seconds: ${10 * SECONDS}.
Enables entering credentials on the Credentials tab. Use when you do not include credentials in the JDBC connection string.
Maximum number of records to include in a batch.
Maximum number of characters to be read in a Clob field. Larger data is truncated.

entry.p: Maximum number of bytes to be read in a Blob field.

row.entry: Format of change capture data. Use when processing change capture data.
Rolls back the entire batch when an error occurs within the batch.
Determines how the stage inserts records. Select to allow inserts of multiple rows at a time. Clear to insert a single row at a time.

Defines the number of parameters allowed in the prepared statement for multi-row inserts.
Use -1 to disable the parameter limit. Default is -1.

Additional JDBC configuration properties to use. To add properties, click Add and define the JDBC property name and value.
Use the property names and values as expected by JDBC.

p.draft-comment: table-JDBCAdvProps - JDBC Lookup uses the whole table. JDBC Consumer uses rows but has its own. JDBC Tee uses some rows. Producer uses a bunch of rows. Oracle CDC uses all rows but Auto Commit. – note updated LC 2/9/17

row.entry:
The maximum number of connections to create.
Default is 1. The recommended value is 1.

The minimum number of connections to create and maintain. To define a fixed connection pool, set to the same value as Maximum Pool Size.
Default is 1.

Maximum time to wait for a connection. Use a time constant in an expression to define
        the time increment. 
Default is 30 seconds, defined as follows:
         ${30 * SECONDS}

Maximum time to allow a connection to idle. Use a time constant in an expression to
        define the time increment. 
Use 0 to avoid removing any idle connections.
Default is
         30 minutes, defined as follows: ${30 * MINUTES}

Maximum lifetime for a connection. Use a time constant in an expression to define the
        time increment. 
Use 0 to avoid removing any idle connections.
Default is 30
         seconds, defined as follows: ${30 * SECONDS}

Determines whether auto-commit mode is enabled or disabled for the connection.
Disabled by default.

Creates read-only connections to avoid any type of write.
Enabled by default. Disabling this property is not recommended.

Transaction isolation level used to connect to the database.
Default is the default transaction isolation level set for the database. You can override the database default by setting the level to any of the following:
Read committed
Read uncommitted
Repeatable read
Serializable

conbody.draft-comment: table-S3AdvProps Amazon S3 destination uses the whole table, S3 and Kinesis Consumer use certain rows.

row.entry: Specifies whether to use a proxy to connect to Amazon S3.
Thread Pool Size for Parallel Uploads

Size of the thread pool for parallel uploads. Used when writing to multiple partitions and writing large objects in multiple parts.
When writing to multiple partitions, setting this property up to the number of partitions being written to can improve performance.
For more information about this and the following properties, see the Amazon S3 TransferManager documentation.
Minimum batch size in bytes for the destination to use multipart uploads.
Minimum part size in bytes for multipart uploads.

conbody.draft-comment: HBase, Redis, and Static Lookup processors use rows in the table. See below for same properties worded slightly differently for JDBC Lookup. Make same changes in both places.

row.entry:
Mode used to perform the lookups:
Per Batch - Performs a bulk lookup of all keys in a batch. The processor performs a single lookup for each batch.
Per Key in Each Record - Performs individual lookups of each key in each record. If you configure multiple key expressions, the processor performs multiple lookups for each record.
Default is Per Batch.
Specifies whether to locally cache the returned key-value pairs.

Maximum number of key-value pairs to cache. When the maximum number is reached, the processor evicts the oldest key-value pairs from the cache.
Default is -1, which means unlimited.

Policy used to evict key-value pairs from the local cache when the expiration time has passed:
Expire After Last Access - Measures the expiration time since the key-value pair was last accessed by a read or a write.
Expire After Last Write - Measures the expiration time since the key-value pair was created, or since the value was last replaced.

Amount of time that a key-value pair can remain in the local cache without being accessed or written to.
Default is 1 second.

Unit of time for the expiration time.
Default is seconds.

conbody.draft-comment: JDBC Lookup and Salesforce Lookup use rows in this table

row.entry: Specifies whether to locally cache the returned values.

Maximum number of values to cache. When the maximum number is reached, the processor evicts the oldest values from the cache.
Default is -1, which means unlimited.

Policy used to evict values from the local cache when the expiration time has passed:
Expire After Last Access - Measures the expiration time since the value was last accessed by a read or a write.
Expire After Last Write - Measures the expiration time since the value was created, or since the value was last replaced.

Amount of time that a value can remain in the local cache without being accessed or written to.
Default is 1 second.

Unit of time for the expiration time.
Default is seconds.

conbody.draft-comment: HBase destination and HBase Lookup use rows and entries in this table

row.entry:
Comma-separated list of servers in the ZooKeeper quorum. Use the following format: <host>.<domain>.com
To ensure a connection, enter additional broker URIs.
Port number clients use to connect to the ZooKeeper servers.
Root node that contains all znodes used by the HBase cluster.

Name of the HBase table to use. Enter a table name or a namespace and table name as follows: <namespace>.<tablename>.
If you do not enter a table name, HBase uses the default namespace.

Uses Kerberos credentials to connect to HBase.
When selected, uses the Kerberos principal and keytab defined in the configuration file, $SDC_CONF/sdc.properties.

The HBase user to use to write to HBase. When using this property, make sure HBase is configured appropriately.
When not configured, the pipeline uses the currently logged in user.
Not configurable when is configured to use the currently logged in user. For more information, see .

Location of the HDFS configuration files.
For a Cloudera Manager installation, enter hbase-conf. For all other installations, use a directory or symlink within the resources directory.
You can use the following file with HBase:
Properties in the configuration files are overridden by individual properties defined in the stage.

entry.p: Additional HBase configuration properties to use.
To add properties, click Add and define the property name and value. Use the property names and values as expected by HBase.

conbody.draft-comment: Redis origin, destination, and Lookup processor use this row

row.entry:
URI of the Redis server. Use the following format:redis://<host name>:<port number>/<database>
You can omit the database if the server uses the default database.
You can optionally include your password to log in to the Redis server. For example:redis://:<password>@<host name>:<port number>/<database>

conbody.draft-comment: MongoDB origin and destination use all rows in this table. They use the description for the Enable SSL property

row.entry:
Maximum number of connections for each host.
Default is 100.

Minimum number of connections for each host.
Default is 0.

Maximum time in milliseconds to wait for a connection.
Default is 10,000.

Maximum time in milliseconds that a pooled connection can remain idle. When a pooled connection exceeds the idle time, the connection is closed. Use 0 to opt out of this property.
Default is 0.

Maximum time in milliseconds that a pooled connection can be active. When a pooled connection exceeds the lifetime, the connection is closed. Use 0 to opt out of this property.
Default is 0.

Maximum time in milliseconds that a thread can wait for a connection to become available. Use 0 to opt out of this property. Use a negative value to wait indefinitely.
Default is 120,000.

Maximum time in milliseconds that waits for a server selection before throwing an exception. If you use 0, an exception is thrown immediately if no server is available. Use a negative value to wait indefinitely.
Default is 30,000.
Threads Allowed to Block for Connection Multiplier

Multiplier that determines the maximum number of threads that can wait for a connection to become available from the pool. This number multiplied by the Connections Per Host value determines the maximum number of threads.
Default is 5.

The frequency in milliseconds at which attempts to determine the current state of each server in the cluster.
Default is 10,000.

Minimum heartbeat frequency in milliseconds. waits at least this long before checking the state of each server.
Default is 500.

Maximum time in milliseconds to wait for a connection used for the cluster heartbeat.
Default is 20,000.

Maximum time in milliseconds for a socket timeout for connections used for the cluster heartbeat.
Default is 20,000.

Local threshold in milliseconds. Requests are sent to a server whose ping time is less than or equal to the server with the fastest ping time plus the local threshold value.
Default is 15.
Required replica set name to use for the cluster.
Specifies whether to enable cursor finalizers.
Specifies whether to enable socket keep alive.

Maximum time in milliseconds for the socket timeout. Use 0 to opt out of this property.
Default is 0.
Specifies whether invalid host names are allowed in SSL/TLS certificates.

conbody.draft-comment: Salesforce origin, Salesforce Lookup processor, and Salesforce destination use the first three rows in this table, and use the description of the last row. Wave Analytics destination uses the first two rows in the table. Salesforce origin and Lookup processor use the last row.

row.entry: Salesforce username in the following email format: <text>@<text>.com.

Salesforce SOAP API authentication endpoint. Enter one of the following values:
login.salesforce.com - Use to connect to a Production or Developer Edition organization.
test.salesforce.com - Use to connect to a sandbox organization.
Default is login.salesforce.com.

Salesforce API version to use to connect to Salesforce.
Default is . If you change the version, you also must download the relevant JAR files from Salesforce Web Services Connector (WSC).

Determines whether the SOQL query also retrieves deleted records from the Salesforce recycle bin.
The query can retrieve deleted records when the stage uses the Salesforce SOAP API or the Bulk API version 39.0 or later. Earlier versions of the Bulk API do not support retrieving deleted records.

conbody.draft-comment: All Salesforce stages use the rows in this table

row.entry: Specifies whether to use an HTTP proxy to connect to Salesforce.
Specifies whether the proxy requires a user name and password.

conbody.draft-comment: Description of each role is conref'd in the LDAP and File Authentication sections. The whole table is conrefed by the Roles topic. (LC 2/17)

row.entry: Perform any task. Can perform all tasks listed below, as well as start and stop , view configuration, JVM metrics, and log information. Install libraries using the Package Manager.
Start and stop pipelines, monitor pipelines, configure and reset alerts. Take, review, and manage snapshots.
Create and configure pipelines and alerts, preview data, and monitor the pipeline. Import pipelines.
View pipelines and alerts, and general monitoring information. Export a pipeline.

p.draft-comment: Permissions table - used in Pipeline Maintenance > Sharing Pipelines and Configuring > Users, Groups, blah blah > Pipeline Permissions

row.entry: View and monitor the pipeline, and see alerts. View existing snapshot data.
Start and stop the pipeline. Preview data and take a snapshot.

p.draft-comment: The following User-Roles table used in Users, Groups, Roles, Perms > Users and also in File-Based Authentication > Step 2.

conbody.draft-comment: The following User-Roles table used in Users, Groups, Roles, Perms > Users and also in File-Based Authentication > Step 2.
Descriptions are used in MapR DB JSON origin and destination

entry.p: If you do not include a path to the table, the stage assumes that the table exists in the user's home directory. For example, /user/<user name>/<table name>.

You can include a path relative to the user's home directory or an absolute path when you enter the table name. For tables in a default cluster, specify the absolute path as /<table path>. For tables in a specific cluster, specify the absolute path as /mapr/<cluster name>/<table path>.

conbody.draft-comment: The following table is used by the Salesforce origin and the Salesforce Lookup processor

row.entry: Provides the original Salesforce data type for the field.
Provides the original length for all string and textarea fields.
Provides the original precision for all double fields.
Provides the original scale for all double fields.
Provides the maximum number of digits for all integer fields.

conbody.draft-comment: These rows are used by the Groovy, JavaScript, Jython Evaluators

row.entry:
Optional initialization script to use in the processor.
Use to set up connections or resources required by the processor. Runs once when the pipeline starts.

Main processing script to use in the processor.
Runs for each record or each batch of data, based on the configured processing mode.

Optional destroy script to use in the processor.
Use to close any connections or resources required by the processor. Runs once when the pipeline stops.

conbody.draft-comment: These rows are used by the MQTT Subscriber and MQTT Publisher

row.entry:
MQTT Broker URL. Enter in the following format:<tcp | ssl>://<hostname>:<port>
Use ssl for secure connections to the broker.
For example:tcp://localhost:1883

MQTT Client ID. The ID must be unique across all clients connecting to the same broker.
You can define an expression that evaluates to the client ID. For example, you can enter the following expression to use the unique pipeline ID as the client ID:${pipeline:id()}

Determines the quality of service level used to guarantee message delivery:
At Most Once (0)
At Least Once (1)
Exactly Once (2)
For more information, see the HiveMQ documentation on quality of service levels.
Enables entering credentials on the Credentials tab. Use when the MQTT broker requires a user name and password.
